TableÂ 1 presents the results obtained across various language pairs and LLMs, in terms of COMET and BLEURT scores. Results with BLEU and ChrF scores, showing similar trends, are given in AppendixÂ A.3. As expected, the translation performance of LLMs generally improves with scale, but also with recency. For instance, the more recent Mistral-7B significantly outperforms Llama2-7B, despite their similar sizes (7 billion parameters). ALMA-7B and Tower-7B emerge as the top-performing LLMs across all language pairs, confirming the merits of MT-specific fine-tuning of LLMs.
Tower-7B has better performance than ALMA-7B in all pairs except isââ\rightarrowâen, where the latter dominates.333This is because isââ\rightarrowâen data was not used in the fine-tuning stages of Tower, contrary to ALMA, leading to catastrophic forgetting, as is visible when comparing the scores of Tower with those of its parent model, Llama2. We do not provide the isââ\rightarrowâen scores of smaller LLMs (PolyLM and XGLM) due to their poor capabilities in the low-resource Icelandic language.
The BLEURT scores of various methods, LLMs and language pairs from TableÂ 1 are represented as radar charts in FigureÂ 6. The shapes corresponding to our proposal, QE-fusion, always extend outside the others (only beam search, MBR with COMET and QE-reranking are plotted, for simplicity), for all of the four LLMs represented: Llama2-7B, Mistral-7B, ALMA-7B, and TowerBase-7B. The latter two models, though fine-tuned for MT, have large differences for isââ\rightarrowâen and deââ\rightarrowâfr.

The COMET and BLEURT scores of our approach applied to
multilingual NMT models, namely NLLB-1.3B and NLLB-3.3B, are presented in TableÂ 2 (BLEU and ChrF scores are in AppendixÂ A.3). We observe that NMT models have a slight edge over general-purpose LLMs (Llama2 and Mistral) while their MT-fine-tuned counterparts, ALMA and Tower, achieve similar or better performance. Similar to the results with LLMs, our approach consistently outperforms beam search and reranking approaches.
The gap between our approach and QE-reranking is slightly smaller in the case of NMT models, which we attribute to the lower diversity of the generated candidates. We test this hypothesis in SectionÂ 6.3.
FigureÂ 6 also shows the BLEURT scores for the two NMT models from TableÂ 2, over the same language pairs as above, excluding zhââ\rightarrowâen. Again, QE-fusion extends outside the other shapes for both NMT models.

references: The results presented in TableÂ 3 indicate that QE-reranking is more efficient in mitigating hallucinations compared to MBR with COMET, consistent with prior work Farinhas etÂ al. (2023). Remarkably, QE-fusion reduces hallucinations even further, outperforming all other methods across different models and language pairs, in nine out of ten cases.

S6.T4.3.caption: Translation performance on the WMT22 en de test set. We compare QE-fusion against standard fine-tuning (FT), in-context learning (ICL), and LMCor.
S6.T4.3.table:
Model BLEU COMET BLEURT
T5-base (FT) 23.32 75.22 64.57
XGLM-2.9B (ICL) 17.32 74.54 66.47
\hdashline+ LMCor 25.15 77.45 68.41
+ QE-fusion 18.60 81.79 71.17
references:
TableÂ 4 shows that LMCor outperforms fine-tuned T5 and in-context learning across all metrics. However, QE-fusion achieves significant improvements of 4 and 3 points in COMET and BLEURT, respectively, despite trailing in BLEU. This
underscores the limitations of surface-based metrics and
suggests that higher BLEU scores may be attained by models specifically trained for MT, which can mimic the translation style of the training data (see Appendix A.3).

We provide the scores of the surface-based BLEU and ChrF metrics for LLMs in TableÂ 6. The overall performance trends align with those of neural-based metrics, indicating that larger models consistently achieve higher scores. Once again, QE-fusion consistently surpasses reranking approaches. However, regarding surface-based metrics, beam search or greedy decoding frequently emerge as the top-performing methods, with our approach securing the second position.
Still, our approach outperforms all other sampling-based methods.

references: TableÂ 7 presents BLEU and ChrF scores for the NMT models. Firstly, we observe that the NMT models perform significantly better than the LLMs in terms of surface-based metrics, which is consistent with previous findings Chowdhery etÂ al. (2023); Hendy etÂ al. (2023); Zhu etÂ al. (2023). The trend differs slightly compared to LLMs, as methods like QE-reranking and MBR score higher in terms of surface-based metrics, particularly for the high-resource pairs enââ\rightarrowâde and enââ\rightarrowâru. This divergence can be attributed, once again, to the limited diversity of translations generated by MT models, while our approach favors more creative translations, potentially penalized by these metrics. Nevertheless, for pairs where MT models perform worse, such as isââ\rightarrowâen and deââ\rightarrowâfr, QE-fusion consistently outperforms reranking approaches and occasionally beam search.

Moreover, QE-fusion also outperforms the other methods when combined with even larger LLMs, as confirmed by the results obtained with the Llama2 and ALMA models with 13 billion parameters presented in AppendixÂ A.4, TablesÂ 8 and 9, for COMET, BLEURT, BLEU and ChrF scores.
TablesÂ 8 and 9 present the translation scores of the larger versions of Llama2 and ALMA with 13B parameters. The overall trend aligns with other LLMs: QE-fusion significantly outperforms reranking methods.
